subsection.title: Increasing and Decreasing
subsection.p: Most people have intuition about what is means for something to be increasing and what it means for something to be decreasing. However, we need to develop a solid mathematical way of defining increasing and decreasing.
Before defining increasing and decreasing is will be useful to recall interval notation.
An interval is a set that consists of all the real numbers between two numbers a and b.

The set -2 \le x \le 2 includes its endpoints -2 and 2, so we call it a closed intervalclosed interval, and we denote it by [-2, 2] (see a). The square brackets tell us that the endpoints are included in the interval. An interval that does not include its endpoints, such as -2 \lt x \lt 2, is called an open intervalopen interval, and we denote it with round brackets, (-2, 2) (see b).

warning.p: Do not confuse the open interval (-2, 2) with the point (-2, 2)! The notation is the same, so you must decide from the context whether an interval or a point is being discussed.

subsection.p: We can also discuss infinite intervalsinfinite intervals, such as x\lt 3 and x\ge -1, shown in . We denote the interval x\lt 3 by (-\infty, 3), and the interval x\ge -1 by [-1, \infty). The symbol \infty, for infinity, does not represent a specific real number but rather indicates that the interval continues forever along the real line. Because of this, we will always use a round bracket along side \pm \infty.

Finally, we can combine two or more intervals into a larger set. For example, the set consisting of x\lt -1 or x\gt 2, shown in , is the unionunion of two intervals and is denoted by (-\infty,-2) \cup (2,\infty).

assemblage.title: Definition of Increasing and Decreasing
assemblage.p: Let y = f(x) where a\leq x \leq b.
Then the function f(x) is said to be increasingincreasing on [a,b] if the value of f(x) increases as x increases on [a,b].
Then the function f(x) is said to be decreasingdecreasing on [a,b] if the value of f(x) decreases as x increases on [a,b].

subsection.title: Measuring Steepness
subsection.p: Imagine you are an ant carrying a heavy burden along one of the two paths shown in . Which path is more difficult? Most ants would agree that the steeper path is more difficult.

sidebyside.p: But what exactly is steepness? It is not merely the gain in altitude, because even a gentle incline will reach a great height eventually. Steepness measures how sharply the altitude increases. An ant finds the second path more difficult, or steeper, because it rises 5 feet while the first path rises only 2 feet over the same horizontal distance.

subsection.p: To compare the steepness of two inclined paths, we compute the ratio of change in altitude to change in horizontal distance for each path.

statement.p: Which is steeper, Stony Point trail, which climbs 400 feet over a horizontal distance of 2500 feet, or Lone Pine trail, which climbs 360 feet over a horizontal distance of 1800 feet?

solution.p: For each trail, we compute the ratio of vertical gain to horizontal distance. For Stony Point trail, the ratio is \frac{400 \text{ feet}}{2500 \text{ feet}}= 0.16 and for Lone Pine trail, the ratio is \frac{360 \text{ feet}}{1800 \text{ feet}}= 0.20. Lone Pine trail is steeper, because it has a vertical gain of 0.20 foot for every foot traveled horizontally. Or, in more practical units, Lone Pine trail rises 20 feet for every 100 feet of horizontal distance, whereas Stony Point trail rises only 16 feet over a horizontal distance of 100 feet.

statement.p: Which is steeper, a staircase that rises 10 feet over a horizontal distance of 4 feet, or the steps in the football stadium, which rise 20 yards over a horizontal distance of 12 yards?

subsection.p: The slope of a line is a number. It tells us how much the y-coordinates of points on the line increase when we increase their x-coordinates by 1 unit. For instance, the slope \dfrac{3}{4} in means that the y-coordinate increases by \dfrac{3}{4} unit when the x-coordinate increases by 1 unit. For increasing graphs, a larger slope indicates a greater increase in altitude, and hence a steeper line.

subsection.title: Notation for Slope
subsection.p: We use a shorthand notation for the ratio that defines slope, \frac{\text{change in }y\text{-coordinate}}{\text{change in }x\text{-coordinate}}. The symbol \Delta (the Greek letter delta) is used in mathematics to denote change in. In particular, \Delta y means change in y-coordinate, and \Delta x means change in x-coordinate. We also use the letter m to stand for slope. With these symbols, we can write the definition of slope as follows.

assemblage.title: Notation for Slope
assemblage.p: The slopeslope of a line is given by \frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{\text{change in }y\text{-coordinate}}{\text{change in }x\text{-coordinate}}\text{, }~\Delta x\ne 0.

subsection.title: Lines Have Constant Slope
subsection.p: How do we know which two points to choose when we want to compute the slope of a line? It turns out that any two points on the line will do.

subsection.title: Meaning of Slope

sidebyside.p: Consider the graph of the equation C = 5 + 3t showing the cost of a bicycle rental in terms of the length of the rental. We can choose any two points on the line to compute its slope. Using points P and Q as shown, we find that m = \frac{\Delta C}{\Delta t}= \frac{9}{3}=3 The slope of the line is 3.

subsection.p: What does this value mean for the cost of renting a bicycle? The expression \frac{\Delta C}{\Delta t}= \frac{9}{3} stands for \frac{\text{change in cost}}{\text{change in time}}= \frac{9 \text{ dollars }}{3 \text{ hours}}.

If we increase the length of the rental by 3 hours, the cost of the rental increases by 9 dollars. The slope gives the rate of increase in the rental fee, 3 dollars per hour. In general, we can make the following statement.

assemblage.title: Rate of Change
assemblage.p: The slope of a line measures the rate of changerate of change of the output variable with respect to the input variable.

subsection.p: Depending on the variables involved, this rate might be interpreted as a rate of growth or a rate of speed. A negative slope might represent a rate of decrease or a rate of consumption. The slope of a graph can give us valuable information about the variables.

subsection.title: A Formula for Slope
subsection.p: We have defined the slope of a line to be the ratio m = \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} as we move from one point to another on the line. So far, we have computed \Delta y and \Delta x by counting squares on the graph, but this method is not always practical. All we really need are the coordinates of two points on the graph.
We will use subscriptssubscripts to distinguish the two points:
P_1 means first point and P_2 means second point.
We denote the coordinates of P_1 by (x_1, y_1) and the coordinates of P_2 by (x_2, y_2).

sidebyside.p: Now consider a specific example. The line through the two points P_1 (2, 9) and P_2 (7,-6) is shown in . We can find \Delta x by subtracting the x-coordinates of the points: \Delta x = 7 - 2 = 5 In general, we have \Delta x = x_2 - x_1 and similarly \Delta y = y_2 - y_1 .

subsection.p: These formulas work even if some of the coordinates are negative; in our example, \Delta y = y_2 - y_1 = -6 - 9 = -15. By counting squares down from P_1 to P_2, we see that \Delta y is indeed -15. The slope of the line in is
We now have a formula for the slope of a line that works even if we do not have a graph.

assemblage.title: Two-Point Slope Formula

statement.p: Compute the slope of the line in using the points Q_1 (6, -3) and Q_2 (4, 3).

solution.p: Substitute the coordinates of Q_1 and Q_2 into the slope formula to find m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1}= \frac{3 - (-3)}{4 - 6} = \frac{6}{-2}= -3. This value for the slope, -3, is the same value found above.
